turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: I see. Junkyards. What is the fascination there?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: Is it the machines? The noise? The people?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: No. It's the junk. I like to look at junk.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: What else do you like?

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: That's very interesting, Harold, and I think very illuminative. There seems to be a definite pattern emerging.  Your fondness for useless machines and demolitions seems indicative of your present emotional state, your self-destructive urges and your alienation from the regular social interaction. What do you think? And of course this pattern once isolated can be coped with. Recognize the problem and you are half way on the road to its solution. But tell me, what do you do for <u>fun</u>? What activity gives you a different sense of enjoyment than the others? What do you find fulfilling? What gives you that certain satisfaction?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I go to funerals.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: Harold?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: You don't seem to be listening. I asked do you have any friends?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: None at all?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Well, maybe one.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: Would you care to talk about this friend?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: Is this a friend you had when you were away at school?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: I see.  Were you happy at school, Harold?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: You liked your teachers?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: Your classmates?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: Your studies?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: Then why did you leave?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I burnt down the Chemistry building.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: We are not relating today, Harold. I sense a definite resistance. A lack of true and helpful communication. I find you a very interesting case, Harold, but this reluctance of yours is detrimental to the psycho-analytical process, and can only hinder the possibility of effective treatment. Do you understand?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: Very well.  Now your mother tells me she is arranging several dates for you with some young ladies. How do you feel about that?

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: I see. Tell me, Harold, do you remember your father at all?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: No.  I'd have liked to.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'd have liked to talk to him.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: What would you say?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'd show him my hearse. And my room, and stuff.

turns.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
turns.text: What kind of stuff?

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: Good idea of yours to come out here, Harold. It's a lovely spot.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Thank you, Uncle.

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: Call me "sir," Harold. First thing you learn in the Army - an officer deserves your respect.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: Perfectly lovely. You know, this is what we're defending. Everything that's good and beautiful in the American way of life. Oh, there's some nut peace petitioner over there. Let's go off this way. Those crazy Commie bastards. I don't know why we tolerate 'em. Parasites.

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: Let's examine the facts on it. I say this country has been too harsh in its outright condemnation of war. I say you can point to many material advantages brought about by a crisis and conflict policy. Hell, World War II gave us the ballpoint pen. That's common knowledge.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: During wartime the national suicide rate goes down.

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: Is that a fact? Well, that fits in right along with everything I've been saying. War is not all black.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: War is not all black.

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: And so I ask you - why the hell did we give up on the Germans? Those damn politicians in Washington chalked them up on our side and the wars ever since have been a national disgrace. Hell, look at history. The two best wars this country has fought were against the Jerries. Now I say, get the Krauts on the other side of the fence where they belong, and let's get back to the kind of enemy worth killing and the kind of war this whole country can support.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Jeez, sir. That's pretty strong stuff.

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: They came at me from all sides, hundreds of 'em. We kept firing - Zat-Tat-Tat-Tat! "Throw the grenades," I shouted. "Mac, throw the grenades!" "He's dead," Joe said, and kept right on feeding me bullets.  Zat-Tat-Tat-Tat!  They kept falling, but they kept coming. Bullets whizzing all around me. Zot! Joe falls back with a neat red hole in his head. I thought I was done for. But I kept firing. Zat-Tat-Tat! Only one thought kept me going. Kill! Kill! For Mac, and Joe, and the rest of the guys. Kill! - a blinding flash. I wake up on a stretcher. "Did we hold?" I asked the medic. "Yes, sir," he said, and I slipped into unconsciousness.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Jeez! That's a great story,

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: Well, you'll soon have stories like that to tell of your own.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You think so, sir?

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: Sure. Be able to tell your children. Something for them to look up to. Be proud of.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I hope so, sir. Golly I never knew it could be so exciting.

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: It's the greatest excitement in the world.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: To pit your own life against another.

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: To kill. The taste of blood in your mouth.

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: The moment of truth.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Another man's life in your sights.

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: ZAT!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Will they really teach me to shoot?

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: Oh, sure. A variety of weapons.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: And to use the bayonet? PACHOIE!

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: Oh sure.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: How about hand-to-hand combat?

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: To strangle someone. Choke him. Squeeze out his life between your hands.

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: Eh?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: How about to slit his throat?

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: Well, I don't...

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: I'd like that. You could see the blood squirt out.

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: Harold, I think you're getting carried away here.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Sir, how about souvenirs?

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: Souvenirs?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Of your kill - ears, nose, scalp, privates.

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: Harold!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: What's the chance of getting one of these?

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Boy, to think I could maybe make my own.

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: Harold! That's <u>disgusting</u>!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Parasite!

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: Harold!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Crazy parasite! Commie bastard! Get out of here.

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: Harold, calm down! This is...

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: She's a Commie pig. We're going to nail every last one...

turns.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
turns.text: Stay where you are, Harold .

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: She took my head.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Good afternoon, Officer. Bit of trouble here?

turns.speaker: OFFICER
turns.text: Yes, ma'am. Somebody had some trouble parking.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Well, it's a tricky turn.

turns.speaker: OFFICER
turns.text: Eh, yes, ma'm.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Tell me --  -- is that car parked all right?

turns.speaker: OFFICER
turns.text: Oh yes. That's fine.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Well, thank you. Eh, officer, you might turn off the radio. Saves the battery.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Ah! There you are, madam. Were not you the lady who drove my car off yesterday?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Was that the one with the St. Christopher medal on the dashboard?

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Then I suppose it was me. Get in, Harold.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Were you also the one who painted the statues?

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, yes. How did you like that?

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Well, I didn't.

turns.speaker: MAUDE
turns.text: Oh, don't be too discouraged. For aesthetic appreciation - always a little time.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: But wait...

turns.speaker: PINHEAD
turns.text: Oh, Kirsty; so eager to play, so reluctant to admit it.

turns.speaker: FEMALE CENOBITE
turns.text: Perhaps you're teasing us. Are you teasing us?

turns.speaker: PINHEAD
turns.text: It's different for us.

turns.speaker: FEMALE CENOBITE
turns.text: We've always been here.

turns.speaker: PINHEAD
turns.text: We have no more surprises.

turns.speaker: PINHEAD
turns.text: Oh. No Boxes. Such a shame.

turns.speaker: FEMALE CENOBITE
turns.text: No more delays, Kirsty. No more teasing. Time to play.

turns.speaker: PINHEAD
turns.text: Time to play.

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: Well, well. All my family together again. How very sweet.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Julia.

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: Frank.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I knew you'd come.

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: You knew?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yes. You're a girl who remembers her promises.

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: Oh, I do. I do.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Oh, right. Daddy's died and gone to heaven, eh?

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: Yes!

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Shit. Bull. Shit.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: See? He's here. You should learn to believe your Uncle Frank.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: No! He SHOULDN'T be here! It SHOULD'VE been a trick!

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: 'Fraid not, baby. He belongs here. With me. We're the same. Brothers. Equal and opposite. Pure appetite. Pure banality. Too much feeling. None at all.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: He... he loved me.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Don't waste your tears. Look at him!

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: Daddy! Daddy! I love you! Help me!

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I'm your Daddy now, Kirsty.

turns.speaker: MALAHIDE
turns.text: Yes... Yes. You look...

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: Surreal? Strange? Nightmarish?

turns.speaker: MALAHIDE
turns.text: No. You look...

turns.speaker: MALAHIDE
turns.text: It's a beautiful dress...

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: MALAHIDE
turns.text: She's done it.

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: She certainly has.

turns.speaker: MALAHIDE
turns.text: It's coming.

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: It certainly is.

turns.speaker: MALAHIDE
turns.text: I want to go back!

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: Sorry, friend. No day trips to Hell. Here you are. Here you stay. And forward the only way to go.

turns.speaker: MALAHIDE
turns.text: I knew you'd come back.

turns.speaker: JULIA
turns.text: I'm a girl who keeps her promises.

turns.speaker: KYLE
turns.text: So... You're Kirsty, huh?

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: You a doctor, too?

turns.speaker: KYLE
turns.text: Sad, huh? She's been here six months. Her name's TIFFANY.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: What's the matter with her?

turns.speaker: KYLE
turns.text: Almost complete withdrawal. She hasn't said a word for nearly two years.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: God, that's terrible.

turns.speaker: KYLE
turns.text: Yeah. Doctor Malahide's got her doing these jig-saws and things, though. Says it's helping to bring her out.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: I... I had a visitor.

turns.speaker: KYLE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: Oh, Jesus. I can't explain. It's... it's. I don't know how to help! I have to save him and I don't know how to help!

turns.speaker: KYLE
turns.text: Kirsty, I'm sorry... don't understand. I...

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: I know. No-one can. But I have to save him. Where's the other doctor? He said He'd listen. He promised.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: Help. No, no-one can help. I just want someone to listen or I WILL go crazy.

turns.speaker: KYLE
turns.text: If anyone can help, HE can.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: No bad dreams.

turns.speaker: KYLE
turns.text: So you slept O.K.?

turns.speaker: KYLE
turns.text: Well, the sofa isn't often used for sleeping on...

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: Oh yeah? On your own a lot, Huh?

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: And you're sure it was a woman?

turns.speaker: KYLE
turns.text: God, I wish I could say no. This is going to do terrible things to my attitude, you know.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: Don't worry about it. Your attitude sucks anyway.

turns.speaker: KYLE
turns.text: Hey, so for it. Don't let pity stop you. I'm down. Nail me.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: The box. I need the box.

turns.speaker: KYLE
turns.text: The box? Like in your story? Like in his house?

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: KYLE
turns.text: The Boxes. In the House. I told you.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: KYLE
turns.text: The boxes! I TOLD you.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: You DIDN'T tell me. Do you mean Malahide's got...

turns.speaker: KYLE
turns.text: Yeah. The things you were talking about.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: Get out of the way.

turns.speaker: KYLE
turns.text: Are you crazy?

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: I don't know, Kyle. You're the fucking expert. Now get out of the way!

turns.speaker: KYLE
turns.text: WHY?

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: Because I'm going to get my father!

turns.speaker: KYLE
turns.text: O.K. Let's go.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: Kyle, you don't have...

turns.speaker: KYLE
turns.text: I KNOW I don't have to. It's just my time of the month to be a complete fucking idiot. O.K.?

turns.speaker: TIFFANY
turns.text: I have to go back. Or it'll never stop.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: What are you talking...

turns.speaker: TIFFANY
turns.text: I've got to finish it.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: Finish what?

turns.speaker: TIFFANY
turns.text: I'm scared.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: No. Don't let it. You've come this far.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: Well... G'bye.

turns.speaker: TIFFANY
turns.text: It's been Hell.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: But I didn't open it! I didn't!

turns.speaker: PINHEAD
turns.text: Then why are you here?

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: I've come for my father!

turns.speaker: PINHEAD
turns.text: But it's true, he is his own Hell. Just as you are in yours.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: And what about you?

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: Wait!

turns.speaker: PINHEAD
turns.text: No more deals, Kirsty. It's your flesh we want to experience, not your skill at bargaining.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: No deals! Just information. Information. Free of charge. No strings. Just information.

turns.speaker: PINHEAD
turns.text: Go on. But trick us again, child, and your suffering will be legendary even in Hell.

turns.speaker: PINHEAD
turns.text: What is this? Someone else you think escaped us, like Frank?

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: No, No, this one didn't escape. You told me you'd always been in Hell. You were wrong. Look at it. LOOK. IT'S YOU.

turns.speaker: PINHEAD
turns.text: Nonsense, I...

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: It's you! You HAVEN'T always been as you are. You were HUMAN. Remember. Remember all your confusions. Think!

turns.speaker: PINHEAD
turns.text: I... remember.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: You were ALL human!

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: Where am I?

turns.speaker: RONSON
turns.text: You're in the Malahide Institute. It's a psychiatric hospital. But, hey, don't feel judged -- it was just the nearest place to bring you. Remember? You and your boyfriend...?

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: Steve...

turns.speaker: RONSON
turns.text: Don't worry. He's O.K. We sent him home hours ago. Jeez, what a story.

turns.speaker: RONSON
turns.text: What was it, kid? Smack? Angel dust? Don't tell me acid's back in fashion?

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: What are you talking about? Who are you?

turns.speaker: RONSON
turns.text: Oh, excuse me...

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: I thought Steve had talked to you?

turns.speaker: RONSON
turns.text: Oh, pardon me. I obviously didn't convey my hesitation to take his story at face-value. No, YOU talk to me. But -- do me a favor? -- none of this DEMONS crap.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: He talked about Demons, huh?

turns.speaker: RONSON
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: RONSON
turns.text: What the hell are you asking me for? Tag it. Move it.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: The mattress... The mattress... JULIA.

turns.speaker: RONSON
turns.text: Easy, easy. Whatever happened, whatever you saw, it's not here now.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: I saw it... him. But I got away. And I took the box. And I solved it. And they came.

turns.speaker: RONSON
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: The Cenobites.

turns.speaker: ABE
turns.text: I need to touch it to "see"...

turns.speaker: MANNING
turns.text: See what??

turns.speaker: ABE
turns.text: The past, the future, whatever this object holds.

turns.speaker: MANNING
turns.text: Is he serious??

turns.speaker: ABE
turns.text: Don't worry about fingerprints. I never had any.

turns.speaker: ABE
turns.text: They were over here, Professor.

turns.speaker: MANNING
turns.text: Oooh!! Who was here? Nixon? Houdini? You mind sharing your mystic insights?

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: Look at them ugly suckers, Blue. One sheet of glass between them and us.

turns.speaker: ABE
turns.text: Story of my life.

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: I break it, they see us, Happy Halloween. No more hiding.  Outside. I could be outside --

turns.speaker: ABE
turns.text: You mean, outside... with her.

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: Don't get psychic with me.

turns.speaker: ABE
turns.text: Nothing psychic about it. You're easy.

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: How am I ever gonna get a girl?? I drive around in a garbage truck

turns.speaker: ABE
turns.text: Liz left us, Red. Take the hint.

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: We don't take hints.

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: Would'ya look at this babies? Made 'em myself. Holy water, silver shavings, white oak: the works.

turns.speaker: ABE
turns.text: Behind this door. A dark entity -- Evil, ancient and hungry.

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: Hey. Stinky. Kitchen's closed.  Whatcha havin'? Six library guards, raw? Plus belts and boots? Man, you're gonna need some heavy fiber to move that out --

turns.speaker: ABE
turns.text: Red, I found something --

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: Nah -- he's taken care of.

turns.speaker: ABE
turns.text: No, listen this: Sammael, the desolate one, lord of the shadows, son of Nergal --

turns.speaker: ABE
turns.text: You were burned by some organic acid.

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: I'm lucky that way.

turns.speaker: ABE
turns.text: Red. How long was it latched onto you?

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: I dunno, maybe five seconds -- ow!

turns.speaker: ABE
turns.text: Touched you five seconds. Laid three eggs.

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: Didn't even buy me a drink.

turns.speaker: ABE
turns.text: Remind me why I keep doing this.

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: Rotten eggs and the safety of mankind.

turns.speaker: ABE
turns.text: Oh, right --

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: That's all for you, Sammy.

turns.speaker: ABE'S VOICE
turns.text: Red -- you need to hear the rest of the information --

turns.speaker: ABE'S VOICE
turns.text: hound of resurrection --

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: See? I don't like that --

turns.speaker: ABE'S VOICE
turns.text: -- Hound of resurrection?

turns.speaker: ABE'S VOICE
turns.text: harbinger of pestilence, seed of destruction --

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: Skip to the end, willya?  How do I kill it -- ?

turns.speaker: ABE'S VOICE
turns.text: It doesn't say --

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: This is an important mission, Sgt. Whitman. I hope you realize that.

turns.speaker: WHITMAN
turns.text: Oh -- you don't wanna know what I think. Topside, now.

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: Sgt. Whitman!! Sgt. Whitman!! May I have a word??

turns.speaker: WHITMAN
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: In private, if you don't mind...

turns.speaker: WHITMAN
turns.text: You are a Catholic??

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: Amongst other things, yes -- but that's hardly the point.

turns.speaker: WHITMAN
turns.text: Here. You'll need one of these.

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: I abhor violence.  Sergeant Whitman, I hope you don't think me mad --

turns.speaker: WHITMAN
turns.text: Three days too late for that one, "professor."

turns.speaker: WHITMAN
turns.text: You're wasting our time: There's nothing on this island but sheep and rocks.

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: Ruins. Not rocks. The remains of Trondham Abbey. Built on an intersection of Ley Lines, the boundaries between our world and the other --

turns.speaker: WHITMAN
turns.text: What a load of crap. Hell, a week ago I hadn't even heard the word parabnormal --

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: "Paranormal"  But -- you read the transmission.

turns.speaker: WHITMAN
turns.text: Half transmission. Nonsense -- German ghost stories!

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: I have seen ghosts, Whitman.

turns.speaker: WHITMAN
turns.text: Oh, I'll bet you have.

turns.speaker: WHITMAN
turns.text: The freak in the gas mask --

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: Karl Ruprecht Kroenen, one of the Reich's top Scientists. Head of the Thule Occult Society.

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: If he's here, this is worse than I thought.

turns.speaker: WHITMAN
turns.text: Air and sea backup. What's closest?

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: Cordon off the area. Something came through.

turns.speaker: WHITMAN
turns.text: From where??!!

turns.speaker: MATLIN
turns.text: It's almost over!!

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: No. It's not.

turns.speaker: MATLIN
turns.text: Do you believe in hell?

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: There is a place -- a dark place where evil slumbers and awaits to return. From there it infects our dreams. Our thoughts. Grigory gave us a glance tonight --

turns.speaker: MATLIN
turns.text: Grigory -- That's Russian, right?  Thought they were on our side...

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: Grigory Yefimovich Rasputin --

turns.speaker: MATLIN
turns.text: C'mon -- Rasputin??

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: Spiritual advisor to the Romanovs.  In 1916, at a dinner in his honor, he was poisoned, shot, stabbed, clubbed, drowned and castrated.

turns.speaker: MATLIN
turns.text: That makes him more than a hundred --

turns.speaker: MATLIN
turns.text: What the hell was that? An ape?

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: No. It was red. Bright red.

turns.speaker: MATLIN
turns.text: It's got a big stone -- in its hand --

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: I think that is its hand.

turns.speaker: MANNING
turns.text: Every time the media get a look at him, they come to me. I'm running out of lies, Trevor.

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: I thought you liked being on TV.

turns.speaker: MANNING
turns.text: I do.  How many escapes?  This year alone: five!

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: Tom -- he's our guest, not a prisoner.

turns.speaker: MANNING
turns.text: Your "guest" happens to be six foot five, bright red, and is government funded.

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: He's just going through a phase --

turns.speaker: MANNING
turns.text: These freaks, Trevor, they give me the creeps. And I'm not the only one. You're up for review. You and your petting zoo.

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: I know where to find him. I'll get him back.

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: A 16th century statue was destroyed. Saint Dionysius the Aeropagite.

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: Who wards off demons.

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: Smuggled into this country by an overzealous curator. The statue, however, was hollow --

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: Reliquary --

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: A prison. The Vatican deemed its contents dangerous enough to include it on the List of Avignon. Of which we hold a copy.

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: Son. About Rasputin --

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: Don't worry. I'll get him soon enough --

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: Listen to me. This time is different. There's more at stake than ever before.

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: How hard can it be? I punched the crap out of that thing that he sent -- ouch!!

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: I worry about you.

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: Me?? C'mon --

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: Well, I won't be around forever, you know?

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: Oh, stop that --  Damn! Be careful, there --

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: Don't look! Turn around.

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: Is it bad?

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: How many buildings does she have to burn? She belongs here!

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: That's not how she feels. She may never feel it.

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: It's her choice --  She's human --

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: Oh, as opposed to -- ?

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: They took his name from this little inscription that was stuck on his tank.

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: Icthyo Sapiens, April 14, 1865.

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: The day Abraham Lincoln died. Hence "Abe" Sapien.

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: How does he know so much about me?

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: Abe possesses a unique frontal lobe.  "Unique." That's a word you'll hear quite a bit around here.

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: Where am I -- exactly, Sir?

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: As you entered the lobby there was an inscription --

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: On the desk, yes. In Latin.

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: Impressive. Do you remember what it said?

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: "In absentia luci, tenebrae vinciunt..."

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: "In the absence of light, darkness prevails." For there are things that go bump in the night, Agent Myers.  We are the ones who bump back.

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: 1958, the occult war finally ends when Adolf Hitler dies.

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: 1945, you mean. Hitler died in '45.

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: Did he, now?

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: I'm in way over my head, I know that much.

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: You're doing fine.

turns.speaker: BROOM
turns.text: And as a father, I worry about him.  In medieval stories, Agent Myers, there's often a young knight, inexperienced but pure of heart...

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: Oh, please. I'm not "pure of heart."

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: Who's the squirt?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Agent Myers is your new liaison.

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: Got tired of me?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Nah. I'll be around, Red, just back in the field.

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: I don't want him.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Manning says I'm too soft on you --  The candy. Give him the candy.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Well, you did break out --

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: I wanted to see her.  It's nobody's business.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: It is. You got yourself on TV again.

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: "Myers", huh? You have a first name??

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Try not to stare. He hates when people stare.

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: Hey, hey, hey. They're playing our song.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: We're on the move.

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: C'mon, Champ! Happy Halloween!!! You're taking me for a walk!

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: At nineteen hundred hours an alarm tripped. B&E. Robbery. Six guards dead --

turns.speaker: HELLBOY
turns.text: Hold on -- hold on -- I thought we checked this place. Fakes, and reproductions.
